caseTitle: ANNA VICTORIA BART Vs NANA EGYEI FOAH
summary: This 2011 Supreme Court of Ghana decision in Anna Victoria Bart Plange v. Nana Egyei Foah centered on a land ownership dispute over a parcel at Momofra Akyenim in the Central Region. The plaintiff claimed ancestral ownership dating to the 19th century, while the defendant admitted prior ownership by the plaintiff's family but asserted a valid 1944 purchase by his ancestors, documented by a registered deed (No. 273A/1945). The trial High Court dismissed the plaintiff's claim, finding insufficient evidence to prove boundaries or disprove the sale, and ruled in favor of the defendantâ€™s counterclaim. The Court of Appeal affirmed, and the Supreme Court upheld this decision, emphasizing the credibility of the defendant's ancient document under Section 130(2) of the Evidence Act, NRCD 323, and the lack of corroborative evidence from the plaintiff to support fraud allegations. The defendant's long possession and the probative value of the registered deed were pivotal in affirming title.
verdict: The appeal was dismissed; the decision of the Court of Appeal affirming the High Court's judgment in favor of the defendant was upheld.
rationaleHighlights: The defendant's registered deed from 1944 qualified as an ancient document under Section 130(2) of the Evidence Act, enhancing its credibility.
The plaintiff failed to provide corroborative evidence to support his claim or allegations of fraud.
The trial court properly evaluated evidence and found the defendant's version more credible.
Long and uninterrupted possession by the defendant supported the claim of ownership.
The burden of proof was not discharged by the plaintiff regarding boundaries and ancestral gift for cultivation.
The Court of Appeal had no reason to disturb the trial court's findings.
Estoppel was considered based on a prior judgment but did not alter the outcome.
The defendant's ancestors paid consideration and obtained a duly executed and registered conveyance.
